identificationModule.briefTitle: Vibrotactile Stimulation for Upper-Extremity Stroke Rehabilitation

descriptionModule.briefSummary:
The goal of this clinical trial is to investigate upper-extremity vibrotactile stimulation with wearables in stroke patients. The main questions it aims to answer are:

Are the wearables well-tolerated by patients? Does the vibrotactile stimulation help regain arm function?

Participants will wear vibrotactile stimulation gloves and shirts for 5 hours daily during their stay at the rehabilitation unit, in addition to conventional therapy. Researchers will compare the treatment group (vibrotactile stimulation wearables) with a control group (conventional therapy only) to see the effects of the vibrotactile stimulation.

armGroups.label: Vibrotactile Stimulation
armGroups.description: Participants wear vibrotactile stimulation shirts and gloves for 5 hours per day, 7 days per week, during their stay at the rehabilitation unit, which is expected to be between 2-3 weeks. Participants wear the devices after conventional therapy is done for the day.

interventions.name: Vibrotactile Stimulation
interventions.description: Shirts contain embedded vibration motors that stimulate the impaired upper-extremity at 18 different locations. The gloves stimulates the fingertips.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Change in Fugl-Meyer Test of Sensorimotor Function After Stroke (UEFM)
primaryOutcomes.description: An impairment based measure consisting of 33 movements that tests motor and sensation of the affected arm. Higher scores indicate less impairment and more isolated motions. Scores are between 0 and 66.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, End of the study (approximately 2-3 weeks, at discharge from the rehabilitation unit).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants with at least one adverse event
secondaryOutcomes.description: Adverse event will only include those that are determined to be related to the vibrotactile stimulation
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: End of the study (approximately 2-3 weeks, at discharge from the rehabilitation unit).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants who completed the therapy
secondaryOutcomes.description: Vibrotactile stimulation therapy feasibility will be assessed by the number of participants who completed the therapy
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: End of the study (approximately 2-3 weeks, at discharge from the rehabilitation unit).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of participants who tolerated the vibrotactile stimulation therapy
secondaryOutcomes.description: Therapy tolerability will be assessed by responses to questionnaires
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: End of the study (approximately 2-3 weeks, at discharge from the rehabilitation unit).

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Change in the modified Ashworth scale
secondaryOutcomes.description: The modified Ashworth scale is used to assess spasticity and tests the resistance to passive movement about a joint with varying degree of velocity. The modified Ashworth scale assigns a grade of spasticity from a 0-4 ordinal scale
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Baseline, End of the study (approximately 2-3 weeks, at discharge from the rehabilitation unit).

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Inpatients at rehabilitation units
* Unilateral left or right sided ischemic stroke within the previous 2 weeks
* Have Upper-Extremity Fugl-Meyer scores between 6 and 58
* Have at least 20 degrees of active shoulder elevation and elbow flexion
* Expected to stay 2-3 weeks in the rehabilitation unit

Exclusion Criteria:

* Under anti-spasticity therapy
* Patients that are dependent on pacemakers
* Patients that have defibrillators
* Have lymphedema or AV fistula for dialysis on an arm
